discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment: @palmskog can you help me?  I don't understand why no CI check have been performed for this PR

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment: @ybertot there was a GitHub outage this Friday that affected CI. The CI will run again if you do a new push (or I can do it if you want).

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment: Only a push can trigger it?

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment:
To my knowledge, there is no other way. But recall that you can do the following locally to do a "no-operation" push in the branch:
```shell
git commit --amend
git push -f
```
The first command changes the SHA of the last commit without changing its content, and then you push the new state to the upstream branch.

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment: thks, I just discovered I had modification I had forgotten to push anyway.

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment:
@ybertot this PR looks good now in CI. However, I think we should also stop to ignore the warnings that you fixed here, for example, the following should be removed in `_CoqProject` and `dune` files:
```
-arg -w -arg -implicit-core-hint-db
-arg -w -arg -duplicate-clear
```

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment: I don't understand.  these lines do not appear in _CoqProject, and there is no dune file.

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment: @palmskog

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment:
Ah, my mistake, I saw some changes I had done locally. But then we may actually want to *add* the following into `_CoqProject`:
```
-arg -w -arg -ambiguous-paths
-arg -w -arg -deprecated-hint-without-locality
-arg -w -arg -deprecated-instance-without-locality
-arg -w -arg -deprecated-syntactic-definition
```
... to make the project warning-free during local compilation, and then remove those as more warnings are fixed.

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment:
I had the same interrogations myself.  What should be the policy: strive for a warning free compilation at the risk of forgetting the work that needs to be done as deprecation looms, or leave the deprecation warnings (and only these) as a reminder?

I would prefer to silence only the ambiguous-path warning.  Would you agree?

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment:
My personal preference is for a warning-free build, with carefully curated GitHub issues and/or draft pull requests to document why some warnings are not addressed (likely due to Coq version compatibility). The main reason is that contributors to a project will not be distracted by irrelevant warnings locally or in the CI.

Still, silencing just the ambiguous-path warning is good as well.

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment:
This made me discover a couple of bugs in the current setup:

1. Makefile.coq.local should never have been checked in, this file is the one that should be used by developers to have their personal choice of warnings removed.  The warnings in Makefile.coq.local should be included in the _CoqProject file.
2. Makefile.coq.local refers to a variable OTHERFAGS when it should have been OTHERFLAGS.  Because of this, any line of the form "-arg -w -arg -ambiguous-paths" for example, is actually ignored at compilation time.

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment: I don't know why Makefile.coq.local is not on the master branch, but it is on both my warning removal branches.

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment: Ok, I found out that @palmskog cleaned up the setup in PR #38, where the flawed Makefile.coq.local was actually removed from the main branch, but this branch has not been rebased yet, so it is still present.

review_discussion.author: palmskog
review_discussion.comment: @ybertot I think this has gotten duplicated from the top of the file. The general convention in nearly all Coq-community projects is to put `-R`/`-Q` and warnings at the top of `_CoqProject`.

commits.author: ggonthier
commits.message:
`inE` robustness

Improve proof script robustness whereby selective rewriting depended on that `inE` expands `x \in A, when `A` is one of the collective `pred`combinators (e.g., `[predU _ & _ ]`), into an expression involving `pred_of_simpl (mem ..) x` subexpression, which need to be further simplified using `/=` or `inE`.
  This will no longer be necessary with future versions of `ssrbool.v`, so this PR removes various hacks that depended on this behavior, such as using explicit  `3!inE` repeat counts.
  As part of this we inlined the `[predU _]` notation in the statement of the `diskN_E` lemma, since expanding it after using the lemma was awkward without the above hacks.

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment: Note that this PR drops compatibility with Coq 8.11 (due to adding the `#[export]` hint locality, which did not exist in 8.11). If this is what we want, I can modify `meta.yml` and CI accordingly.

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment:
I don't understand why you mention only incompatibility with Coq 8.11,  Nix CI for bundle 8.12+1.13, 8.13+1.13, 8.12+1.14, 8.13+1.14 are also failures.

I only understood that this branch is premature for backward compatibility.

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment: You're right that 8.12 and 8.13 are also incompatible (I guess for the same reason with locality). But do you want to modify CI configuration in the same branch right now? Or do it later when it's not WIP anymore?

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment:
I wish to wait until the next math-comp meeting to know what policy should maintained with respect to backward compatibility on the master branch.

For now I am happy to have a branch that contains fixes for many fixable warnings, but I am don't believe all these warning have the same degree of urgency.
 - I fixed several deprecation warnings that may not be timed to the same release of Coq or math-comp
 - the duplicate-clear warnings don't seem to have a deadline, it is just healthy to get rid of them.

I wanted to make the branch a PR so that potential contributors get a chance to know that this work is indeed in progress.  Do you think the README file should be modified to advertise this way of life?

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment:
@ybertot based on my experience in maintaining the [RegLang](https://github.com/coq-community/reglang) project, I believe a reasonable policy in maintaining a project using MathComp is:
- at all times, support all the Coq versions supported by mathcomp `master` branch (this implies tolerating some deprecation warnings by Coq)
- if feasible and on a case-by-case basis, support additional Coq versions with MathComp releases; stop supporting these Coq versions to fix deprecation warnings when reasonable

Hence, I think it may be a good idea to separate out deprecation warning fixes that do not drop Coq versions. See for example [this RegLang PR](https://github.com/coq-community/reglang/pull/25), which we will merge when we drop Coq 8.11 support.

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment: Thanks, I will do as suggested, it may take a few days before I come back to it though.

commits.author: ybertot
commits.message: removed deprecation warnings and most duplicate clear warnings

discussion.author: gares
discussion.comment: nice!

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment: @ybertot do you have any reservations against merging this?

discussion.author: ybertot
discussion.comment:
A small question: why not import `all_ssreflect`?  I understand that `four_color` predates `all_ssreflect` and for this reason there are many files that are not useful, but it would feel even more idiomatic to me.

Is there a technical incompatibility?

discussion.author: palmskog
discussion.comment:
I didn't switch to `all_ssreflect` because a lot of files have very "selective" require-imports, i.e., they only use a small subset of the modules in `all_ssreflect`. Also, many modules from `mathcomp-algebra` are used, but I don't think we want to have `all_algebra`.

In the future, we may want to switch to `all_ssreflect`, but this may require additional refactoring. This PR is to me a pure "re-statement" of existing require-imports.

discussion.author: anton-trunov
discussion.comment:
I did the same fix for the `master` versions of Coq/Mathcomp, but when checking if it can be compiled with Coq 8.7.0 (Mathcomp 1.6.2) and Coq 8.8.2 (Mathcomp 1.7.0) I got two error messages, which can be fixed as follows.

- In https://github.com/math-comp/fourcolor/blob/master/theories/discretize.v#L216 change
```coq
exists s.+1 => e i; case: insubP => // a _ Da m0i  _; rewrite (Ds a) -addSn.
```
into
```coq
exists s.+1 => e i; case: insubP => // a _ Da m0i; rewrite (Ds a) -addSn.
```

- In https://github.com/math-comp/fourcolor/blob/master/theories/gridmap.v#L338 change
```coq
case: k => [|[|k]] IHk ltk Dv; first by rewrite (val_inj Dv).
```
into
```coq
case: k => [|[|k]] IHk ltk Dv; first by rewrite (@val_inj _ _ _ _ _ Dv).
```

These fixes should guarantee that `fourcolor` compiles with a range of Coq versions and a range of Mathcomp versions, including the latest master branches.
We should also explicitly mention that due to `Implicit Arguments` -> `Arguments` we loose the ability to compile with Coq 8.6.
I hope this helps.

discussion.author: ejgallego
discussion.comment: Thanks @anton-trunov , waiting for feedback.

discussion.author: ejgallego
discussion.comment:
> `case: k => [|[|k]] IHk ltk Dv; first by rewrite (@val_inj _ _ _ _ _ Dv).`

I've also applied this suggestion as it seems sensible to me due to the recent change in math-comp.

review_discussion.author: ggonthier
review_discussion.comment:
I'd prefer
```
Arguments leRR x : clear implicits
```
which is more straightforward, and avoids the undocumented `assert` tag.

review_discussion.author: ggonthier
review_discussion.comment: This is fine - I'm not even sure why the old script worked at all!

review_discussion.author: ggonthier
review_discussion.comment:
I'm afraid the issue here is not in `fourcolor`, but with @anton-trunov 's PR math-comp/math-comp#253 .
Unlike other instances of`_inj` lemmas where this was accidental, making the `x1 x2` arguments of `val_inj` explicit was intended. The reason is that unlike most injective functions, `val` is expected to compute, so that `x1` and `x2` can often not be inferred from an equation convertible to `val x1 = val x2`, and hence may often need to be specified when `val_inj` is explicitly applied. Here for instance `(edge u)` can't be found by unification.
  The most obvious fix would be to amend math-comp/math-comp#253 to revert an unwanted change which I let slip by. On the other hand, it's probably not too important an issue since this is apparently the only file where `val_inj` is actually applied, and the first instance actually improves with `x1 x2` implicit, while the second remains passable if one uses the `(x1 := ...)` syntax (which becomes acceptable here as the `x1` name is now documented by `Arguments`. Ideally one should be able to write `((val_inj) (edge u) eu Deu)` as partial application does turn off trailing on-demand implicits; alas, the Coq elaborator does _not_ do that for a 0-ary partial application, as a "special" case (maybe that could be a feature request).

review_discussion.author: ejgallego
review_discussion.comment: Barring the likely welcome improvement on the Coq elaborator, the question on compatibility with previous math-comp versions does remain, do you then prefer the version that relies on the new `Arguments` declaration of `val_inj`?

review_discussion.author: ggonthier
review_discussion.comment:
All things considered I'm inclined to go for the new implicits status, because this keeps the implicits uniform across all infectivity lemmas. However we should nevertheless not rely for now on the bound variable names. Indeed it would be better to rename `[x1 x2]` into `[u1 u2]` as `u` is the conventional variable for a subtype argument in `eqtype.v`.
   Perhaps the better fix in this would be to avoid the direct application of `val_inj` by making the script more declarative, using `have ->: v = u by apply/val_inj` instead of `rewrite` in the first instance, and adding a line:
```
have{Deu} Deu: edge u = eu by apply/val_inj.
```
before a `rewrite -{eu}Deu ...` in the second instance.

review_discussion.author: ejgallego
review_discussion.comment: Thanks! I've amended the script with the version you propose; maybe I'd be good to enable CI in this repository so we can test the modified script builds with the intended software versions first.

review_discussion.author: ejgallego
review_discussion.comment: An additional note, I've always found having to use `have E: type by apply/M` a bit inconsistent w.r.t. the use of `exact/M` in general. Would it make sense to support `have E: type exact/M` ?

review_discussion.author: ggonthier
review_discussion.comment:
That would require making `exact` into a keyword, which might cause all sorts of incompatibilities.
The style in the library is to avoid the redundant `by exact ...` - at some point I made a pass an replaced all of these with `by apply ...`.

commits.author: ejgallego
commits.message:
[coq] Update to work with Coq and math-comp master.

This PR updates the development in order to compile with the Coq
`master` and math-comp `master` branches.

The final version of the amended script was suggested by Georges
Gonthier.

Co-authored-by: Georges Gonthier <georges.gonthier@inria.fr>
